meeting_annotations.speaker: Joshua Weinstein
meeting_annotations.transcript: So one thing that I actually wanted to just bring up although this may, I guess this can tie this into the one thing that that would be useful technologically is that, you know, in the kind of the context of of of sort of molecular transport, one thing that I don't think has been mentioned is just the phenomenon of trogocytosis in immune cells specifically, but just that understanding to what extent that phenomenon extends to other types of cells as well. So you know, so in the case of the interaction between lymphocytes and antigen presenting cells, one of the critical phenomena is the formation of something called the immune synapse where MHC molecules and and T cell receptors complex and what's been observed is that basically they're, you know, basically entire protein complexes can basically transpose from one membrane to the next, right, based on this particular complex. And you can imagine that of course if you have a network of of forcefully interacting cells, then that means that potentially you can have sort of the propagation of of translated proteins over a large length scale in a in a controlled way, right? Whereas of course, you know, once a cell releases a metabolite, it no longer has control over that metabolite. Nevertheless, if you have a network of antigen presenting and T cells that that have formed these specific immune complexes, then you could have sort of a a controlled transport of proteins over very, very large length scales, even though the cells themselves are much smaller.
